actualResults.title: Version Information Disclosure - Apache 2.4.25 and PHP 5.6.40
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate new discovery. The penetration test identified that the web server publicly discloses version information in HTTP headers (Server: Apache/2.4.25 and X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40), enabling targeted reconnaissance. This was not in the expected findings list.

actualResults.title: Sensitive Information Disclosure - MD5 Hash Leakage in Authentication Response
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate new discovery. The penetration test found that MD5 hashes of user-submitted passwords are displayed in error messages ('Incorrect Vault Password: [MD5_HASH]'). This enables hash extraction and offline cracking. This specific vulnerability was not included in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: No Rate Limiting on Password Endpoint - Unrestricted Brute Force Attack
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate new discovery. The penetration test identified complete absence of rate limiting on password authentication attempts, allowing unlimited brute force attacks without delays, throttling, or account lockout. This critical control weakness was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Missing HTTP Security Headers - Misconfiguration
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate new discovery. The penetration test found that all five critical security headers are missing (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, Content-Security-Policy, Strict-Transport-Security). This configuration vulnerability was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Authentication Bypass via Content-Type Mismatch (JSON POST)
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate new discovery. The penetration test identified that sending POST requests with Content-Type: application/json bypasses password validation entirely. The application fails to validate or reject mismatched Content-Type headers and body formats. This specific authentication bypass mechanism was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Authentication Bypass via HTTP Method Mismatch (DELETE/PUT/PATCH Methods)
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate new discovery. The penetration test found that authentication is only enforced for POST requests. Using DELETE, PUT, PATCH, or HEAD methods bypasses password validation entirely. This HTTP method-based bypass was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Privilege Escalation - All Users Elevated to Admin via PHP Type Juggling Authentication Bypass
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate new discovery. The penetration test found that after authenticating via the magic hash bypass, the application grants ADMIN privileges to ALL users regardless of user_id parameter, indicating complete absence of role-based access control (RBAC). This privilege escalation vulnerability compounds the type juggling weakness and was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Weak Session Management - No Session Tokens, Stateless Authentication Required Every Request
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate new discovery. The penetration test identified that the application implements stateless authentication with no session tokens or cookies. Users must re-authenticate with each request. No Set-Cookie headers are ever issued, creating replay attack risks and poor session management. This was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Weak Cryptographic Hash Algorithm (MD5) for Password Storage
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate new discovery. The penetration test comprehensively documented MD5's cryptographic weaknesses for password hashing: no salt, no work factor, collision vulnerabilities since 2004, and susceptibility to rainbow tables and GPU attacks. While related to the type juggling issue, this specific analysis of MD5's fundamental unsuitability was not in the expected findings.

matched.actualTitle: PHP Type Juggling Weak Comparison Authentication Bypass
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the identical vulnerability: weak PHP comparison operator (==) used for MD5 hash comparison in authentication logic. Both specify magic hash values starting with '0e' followed by digits that exploit scientific notation type juggling. Both describe the same exploitation scenario where attackers can bypass authentication using publicly known magic hash payloads like '0e215962017' or '240610708'. The vulnerability location, technical mechanism, and impact are semantically equivalent.
